data:
475 pupils are taught by 60 teachers at HLW St. Veit   (Höhere Bundeslehranstalft für wirtschaftliche Berufe = upper secondary vocational college) an der Glan in southern Austria. During the five year education the curriculum focuses on vocational training in the fields of economy, business, tourism, nutrition and administration. 
Gastronomy is taught in all three streams. (a. ecology; b. 3 foreign languages; c. immersion class)

The main aim is to convey general knowledge and enhance abilities which will enable students to climb the corporate ladder or to enroll in academic studies after graduation. It is HLW’s objective to offer a solid education and to implement intellectually challenging learning experiences.

Fostering communicative abilities are encouraged as well as presenting an appropriate self-portrayal. Additionally pupils are inculcated to value tolerance, thoughtfulness, open-mindedness, solidarity etc.
All faculty members assist our students in developing skills to become independent and self-sufficient adults who will succeed and contribute responsibly in our global community. 

For the last eightteen years the HLW faculty members have encouraged its students to take part in the mobility EU-Leonardo/Erasmus+ vocational training program, providing the individuals working experience abroad and enhancing efficiency and innovation in the field of gastronomy.

During the twelve week compulsory internship in the hospitality industry, the trainee is supervised by a professional food and beverage mentor. The trainee procures a comprehensive view of all the processes at work which the professional is involved. He/She is mentored to develop and promote his/her knowledge in gastronomy, indulge in their foreign language and IT skills, and improve their EU cultural awareness competencies. The beneficiary has the opportunity in working in the floor and bar environment, housekeeping and kitchen, according to the enterprise requirements. 

Number of beneificiaries:
62 students HLW St.Veit/Glan, 
 
During the last couple of years the HLW Erasmusplus team (Mag. H. Pessentheiner, FV. Mag. S. Grojer and Mag. K. Zablatnik-Rotim) and its 24 outstanding school partners ( hotels in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Italy, France and The Netherlands) have built a strong rapport and are interested in improving vocational quality standards. We are all aware of the importance of working hand in hand to make our tomorrow’s work force EURO-fit.

 Outstanding results 2014

 * the official WIFI reception exam was presented in English by the students for the second time

 * HLW St. Veit received the ESIS in November 2013 (Europäisches Sprachinnovationssiegel - European language label) (one of the major facts was that we put emphasis on doing interviews with our hotel managers via Skype video conference)

 * our students show pride that they have a number of foreign friends on their facebook site and enjoy communicating in a foreign language
The Demonstration of Waste Biomass to Synthetic Fuels and Green Hydrogen

TO-SYN-FUEL will demonstrate the conversion of organic waste biomass (Sewage Sludge) into biofuels. The project implements a new integrated process combining Thermo-Catalytic Reforming (TCR©), with hydrogen separation through pressure swing adsorption (PSA), and hydro deoxygenation (HDO), to produce a fully equivalent gasoline and diesel substitute (compliant with EN228 and EN590 European Standards) and green hydrogen for use in transport . The TO-SYN-FUEL project consortium has undoubtedly bought together the leading researchers, industrial technology providers and renewable energy experts from across Europe, in a combined, committed and dedicated research effort to deliver the overarching ambition. Building and extending from previous framework funding this project is designed to set the benchmark for future sustainable development and growth within Europe and will provide a real example to the rest of the world of how sustainable energy, economic, social and environmental needs can successfully be addressed. This project will be the platform for deployment of a subsequent commercial scale facility. This will be the first of its kind to be built anywhere in the world, processing organic industrial wastes directly into transportation grade biofuels fuels which will be a demonstration showcase for future sustainable investment and economic growth across Europe. This project will mark the first pre-commercial scale deployment of the technology processing up to 2100 tonnes per year of dried sewage sludge into 210,000 litres per year of liquid biofuels and up to 30,000 kg of green hydrogen. The scale up of 100 of such plants installed throughout Europe would be sufficient to convert up to 32 million tonnes per year of organic wastes into sustainable biofuels, contributing towards 35 million tonnes of GHG savings and diversion of organic wastes from landfill. This proposal is responding to the European Innovation Call LCE-19.
Sustainable Jet Fuel from Flexible Waste Biomass

FlexJet will build a pre-commercial demonstration plant for the production of advanced aviation biofuel (jet fuel)  from waste vegetable oil and organic solid waste biomass (food waste), successfully demonstrating the SABR-TCR technology (traditional transesterification (TRANS) and Thermo-Catalytic Reforming (TCR) combined with hydrogen separation through pressure swing adsorption (PSA), and hydro deoxygenation (HDO) and hydro cracking/ isomerisation (HC)) to produce a fully equivalent jet fuel (compliant with ASTM D7566 Standards). This project will deliver respective environmental and social sustainability mapping and it will validate a comprehensive exploitation business plan, building on already established end user interest with existing offtake agreements already in place with British Airways. The project plant installed at the source of where the waste arises in BIGA Energie at Hohenstein (Germany) will produce 1,200 ton of jet fuel from 3,482 tonnes of dried organic waste and 1,153 tonnes of waste vegetable oil per year. A subsequent scale-up first commercial plant would be constructed immediately after the project end to produce 25,000 tonnes per year of aviation fuel. The FlexJet project consortium has undoubtedly  bought together the leading researchers, industrial technology providers including airline off takers and renewable energy experts from across Europe, in a combined, committed and dedicated research effort to deliver the overarching ambition. Building and extending from previous framework funding this project is designed to set the benchmark for future sustainable aviation fuel development and growth within Europe and will provide a real example to the rest of the world of how sustainable aviation biofuels can be produced at both large and decentralised scales economically whilst simultaneously addressing social and environmental needs.
Making the transition to a reliable, sustainable and competitive energy system (08.02.03.03)
Making the transition to a reliable, sustainable and competitive energy system (32.04.03.01)

GeoRes aims to expand the scope of the involved teams’ research in addressing some of the outstanding challenges in geotechnical and geoenvironmental engineering: developing innovative solutions for the reuse of waste geomaterials generated by construction and mining industries across Europe. Geomaterial waste represents half of the waste volume generated in EU-27. These waste geomaterials generally exhibit poor engineering characteristics that prevent their direct reuse on construction/mining sites. However, if adequately treated, they could represent an excellent resource for construction purposes with significant money saving and reduction in the environmental footprint, thus contributing to the establishment of a circular economy. To achieve this, GeoRes will develop protocols, software and tools to improve the engineering characteristics of waste geomaterials, and to guarantee the level of performance over the service life of geostructures built from waste geomaterials considering site-specific conditions. The fundamental concern of the research in the GeoRes network is thus to develop strategies and tools for sustainable reuse of waste geomaterials generated by geoengineering activities, and to determine how to turn a waste geomaterial into a valued durable material, with a positive revenue stream. The proposed network is at the interface of two domains of engineering; geotechnical and geoenvironmental. Even today, it is not easy to find researchers with expertise in both geotechnical and geoenvironmental engineering. We intend to form a multidisciplinary and intersectoral consortium composed of 6 academic and 5 industrial beneficiaries and 6 Third Country partners which aim to address this problem. GeoRes will create a multidisciplinary and intersectoral network of creative and innovative researchers and practising engineers ready to face geotechnical and geoenvironmental engineering challenges which arise in the vanguard of technological innovation.
Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions — generating, developing and transferring new skills, knowledge and innovation (15.03.01.01)
A Platform Power Management System and Low Voltage Drive Train for Hybrid and Electric Vehicles

The European hybrid, electric and fuel cell vehicle industry represents 1,600 SME manufacturers and suppliers. They commercialise small volumes of low-emission vehicles, including taxis, delivery vans, factory vehicles and domestic cars. However with current technologies their market is limited and their development has been split between low-cost mass market and expensive high-performance vehicles. These vehicles do not meet customer performance demands, at a price point which is competitive with IC engines. Large vehicle manufacturers overcome this gap and reduce their development costs by platform sharing component technologies. However due to the lack of collaboration within our industry, this platform technology is not available. This proposal addresses this technology gap though the development of an open platform power management system, with customisable performance and efficiency. The platform will be supported by a modular platform drive motor topology, based on a fully scalable axial flux design (100Nm to 1,200Nm cont. torque). The low cost technology will be sufficiently high torque to drive the wheels at a high speed, without requiring an intermediate gearbox. To further drive down cost we will use the housing of the liquid cooled drive motor, as a heat sink for a high current power convertor. This will be achieved by applying a circuit board directly onto the motor housing, using a thermal spraying technology. The project will benefit Europe through increased sales of low-emission vehicles and enable our members to reduce development time by 20% and component cost by 40%. The modular drive motor platform will enable our members to manufacturer desirable vehicles at a competitive price and reduce the total vehicle cost by up to 13%. In addition we will offset imports by EU manufacturing of new drive motors, increasing European revenues by €257 million and profits by €51 million.

The consortium of schools of economiecs (Celje School of Economics, Grammar School Celje - Center, Murska Sobota School of Economics, Secondary School of Economics Maribor, Secondary School Slovenj Gradec and Muta, Secondary School of Economics Ljubljana, Grammar School of Economics and Secondary School Radovljica, Secondary School Jesenice, Secondary School of Business and Economics Koper, Novo mesto School of Economics) has formed partnership with partners in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Spain, Germany, Portugal and Malta for the purpose of collaborating in the mobility project for our secondary school students and teachers from seven of our regions that is taking place from June 2016 until June 2017. We are aiming at organising work placements for 338 of our secondary vocational and technical school students as well as those of grammar school of economics for a period of three to four weeks depending on their programme. The duration of their work placements has been adjusted to their curricula. All partners are aiming at enabling our participants to get an excellent mobility experience, help them upgrade their speaking abilities in English or teach them the basics of Spanish/Portuguese, which means granting their wish. We are going to work hard to broaden their horizons to such an extent so that foreign languages will no longer be a problem but a challenge, we would like them to understand the notion of multicultural existence and be able to live among and with different kinds of people, we want to encourage the use of their professional skills in foreign work environment and gain new professional skills, including soft skills which are becoming increasingly sought after by employers. It is necessary they become aware of the importance of lifelong learning and training as Europe offers excellent opportunites for international cooperation, networking and exchange of expertise. For the majority of our students it will be an all-first time experience: the first flight, for the first time away from their parents for such a long time and so far away from home but all that has so far immensely contributed to their strengthened self-confidence. Teacher training forms an important part of the planned mobility in the two fields that are of utmost importance for all schools of economics: online marketing and start-ups. The new knowledge will lead us to updating of our curricula and better quality education which means we will keep up with the demands of modern society.The project is of utmost importance for all partner schools as mobility activities raise our international profile and attract a greater number of students who want to enrol in our schools. At the same time it provides invaluable new experiences for all of us. We are aiming at increasing the number of mobilities in comparison to previous years, improve the students' openness and independence. At the same time we want to strengthen our collaboration with foreign partners and keep improving our mobility practice by learning also from their rich experience. Mobility is an added value to our educational programmes and it diversifies everyday activities in all our partner schools be it for students or teachers.

The Employability and Entrepreneur Programme (EEP) is an innovative project designed to directly impact levels of unemployment and entrepreneurship within Ireland, targeting graduates of VET colleges. The project seeks to compliment academic achievement with result focused work experience, enhancing learner’s employability, and equipping and energising innovative individuals who look to create their own business, thereby creating employment for themselves, others and contributing to national and European prosperity. 

The project notes the value of living and working abroad for the individual, and for the European Union’s ideal of building mobility, understanding and interculturalism within the community. Youth, innovation and enterprise are at the core of a prosperous future for our citizens.
Medkulturne in strokovne kompetence z roko v roki

The Consortium of Schools of Economics of Eastern Slovenia (Celje School of Economics, Grammar School Celje – Center, Murska Sobota School of Economics, Secondary School of Economics Maribor, Secondary School Slovenj Gradec and Muta, Novo mesto School of Economics) has formed partnership with partners in the United Kingdom, Spain, Ireland, Portugal and Malta for the purpose of collaborating in the mobility project for our secondary school students from five of our regions that is taking place from June 2018 until June 2019. We are aiming at organising work placements for 147 of our secondary vocational and technical school students as well as those of grammar school of economics for a period of 2 or 3 weeks respectively depending on their programme. The duration of their work placements has been adjusted to their curricula. All partners are aiming at enabling our participants to get an excellent mobility experience, we want to help them upgrade their speaking abilities in English or teach them the basics of the Spanish/Portuguese language. We are going to work hard to broaden their horizons to such an extent so that foreign languages will no longer be a problem but a challenge, we would like them to understand the notion of multicultural existence and be able to live among and with different kinds of people, help them adapt to intergenerational environment, we want to encourage the use of their professional skills in foreign work environment and gain new professional skills (mostly the development of entrepreneurial and digital competences), including generic competences which are becoming increasingly sought after by employers. It is necessary they become aware of the importance of lifelong learning and training as Europe offers excellent opportunities for international cooperation, networking and exchange of expertise. Student mobility experience has so far – according to our long-term experience – immensely contributed to their strengthened self-confidence, improved self-worth as well as their linguistic, intercultural and digital competences. In majority we are developing entrepreneurial skills and competences but as we also carry out other educational programmes within our respective schools, the students of the latter have also been involved in the project. 
The project is of utmost importance for all partner schools of the Consortium as mobility activities raise our international profile and attract a greater number of students who want to enrol in our schools. At the same time it provides invaluable new experiences for all of us, including accompanying persons. Nowadays internationalization is a must therefore we are strengthening our collaboration with foreign partners with this project and consequently we keep improving our mobility practice by learning also from their rich experience. Mobility is an added value to our educational programmes and it diversifies everyday activities in all our partner schools be it for students or teachers, especially with the use of eTwinning and School Education Gateway that will enable the upgrade of digital and intercultural competences of both teachers and students.
ESTANCIAS INTERNACIONALES PARA ALUMNADO Y PROFESORADO SEFED

Inform Foundation manages since 1987 the SEFED Programme (Simulation for Business Educational Purposes - The Practice Firm concept) which offers training to around 7.000 students delivered by 800 teachers in vocational training institutions and training for the unemployed in Spain. All these students are being trained in professional and social skills in the business and managing of companies field.

This professional and practical training aimed at finding jobs is well know and acknowledged by the Ministry of Labour issuing a professional certificate with level 1 or 2 by the corresponding Ministry of Education issuing a medium level of vocational training in the administration or comercial field.

Inform has always considered working experiences abroad as part of and an added value to the training delivered in the SEFED Programme. Thus, Erasmus + K1 Programme allows us to support our students and teachers in training activities to achieve and use knowledge, skills and qualifications for their personal development, ocupability and participation in the European labour market. 

The participants of this project are:

- Unemployed students or VET students (mainly young people and women over 25 years old) who are being trained in the SEFED Programme and who would like to improve not only their knowledge and skills in the business field, undertaking working experience stays in Ireland or Great Britain, but their language skills as well. Thus, the project is about to undertake 100 working stays in Irish, Italian, Lithuanian or UK companies and undertake business and management tasks during 4, 5, 8 or 12 weeks as a maximum as participants cannot have longer stays because of personal reasons and the need they have to look for jobs. We include accompanying teachers to help and support students in the firts days of their mobility, so most of them are under 18 and/or they have not any labour experience.

- Teachers and professional staff working for the SEFED Programme: the project allows us to offer a unique opportunity for 40 teachers and professional staff working for the SEFED Programme to be able to share and improve their knwoledge and experiences in a different country and in different organizations, including the transfer of skills and/or methods and innovative ways of doing things in the training field. The transfer of know-how is meant to improve the quality and access to continuous training, to update and adapt the european educational and training systems. When improving knowledge, attitudes and individual skills from all professional staff involved in the SEFED Programme, we will improve in the development of the european labour market and social economy.
The project is based on professional stays in 6 countries, 4 of them already have practice firm networks and are members of Europen-Pen International, from which Inform Foundation is a founding member. Specifically, the professional/pedagogical team will undertake training stays for 5 days in different training organizations which have practice firms in Belgium, Finland, France and Lithuania in which teachers and professional staff will share experiences and best practices regarding the practice firm concept, the organization and management of practice firms as active learning tools.
There will also be some stays in Ireland and UK in which there will be a combination of know-how transfer, innovative learning ways of doing things and application of IT in training. There will also be visits to Irish and English companies so as to undertake job-shadowing.
The participants will be teachers in language skills, foreign trade skills and counselors and training professional staff. There will also be professional staff from Inform Foundation with the aim to set up links with the Central Offices for Practice Firms from the 2 members of Europen-Pen International (Belgium, Finland, France and Lithuania).

The project is meant to improve the quality of the SEFED Programme, the ocupability and competitivity of students and professional staff in training participating in the project.

To prove the success there has been some success indicators set up as the level of labour ocupability of students, the improvement degree of language skills, or the increase of foreign trade orders.

Future-Proofing Critical Skills Through Entrepreneurship (FPE) programme

The Future-Proofing Critical Skills Through Entrepreneurship (FPE) programme provides an innovative approach to prepare and up-skill young people in entrepreneurship. Shaped by real concern about the lack of work-readiness of UK college students it offers a unique 2-week experience blending practical and conceptual training with relevant work placements in two of the most entrepreneurial cities in Europe: Dublin or Barcelona. 

The FPE programme introduces a total of 106 learners enrolled in BTEC Business courses and core members of staff (2 per cohort/per institution) from 4 UK Colleges to the world of startups and cowork spaces (CWSs) at Irish Education Partners (IEP, Dublin) or UP! Training Club (UP!, Barcelona). Addressing skills relevant to future-proof young people’s careers in entrepreneurship, learners will particularly focus on developing their Emotional Intelligence (EI), critical thinking and creative problem solving skills. These skills are increasingly seen as being among the top skills required to succeed in an every changing job market (WEF 2016).  It is the focus on developing EI skills in particular, which sets this training experience apart from other programmes. Our host partners already deliver innovative training activities for young people in this area and have built up a strong expertise in innovative practices. Being shaped by their unique approaches, this programme therefore responds to the need to radically transform and modernise educational approaches that equip young people with relevant skills in entrepreneurship (see BCC2014, CB2014). 

The vocational startup training programme developed by Corkscrew, IEP and UP! will engage learners and staff in a practical learning journey, developing the creative skills to spot business opportunities and identify the feasibility of an idea.  The process of lean startup will be introduced, and how to take an idea to market (website creation, social media marketing and testing). All training is conducted in a real working environment, in a live context, and directly related to the course curriculum, allowing the transfer of credits onto specific modules through the ECVET framework.  Coursework and vocational training will be enhanced and extended by the online resource developed by Corkscrew (2017), which provides access to resources, ideas and an international community of innovative thinkers throughout and beyond the duration of the programme for all stakeholders involved.
The work experience element of the programme, conducted at the cowork spaces in Barcelona and Dublin, enables learners to work on business projects for residents of the space, while UK staff shadow entrepreneurs in their daily working life. Projects will have a direct implication to the host organisations, providing a tangible work project that allows learners to develop confidence and experience in a working startup environment, enabling them to gain unique insights and build up valuable experiences informing their individual profiles. 

Accompanying staff will assess, evaluate and ultimately implement the learnings of the mobility, with the targeted impact of adding aspects of innovative entrepreneurial activities and fostering skills such as Emotional Intelligence to the provision of their UK based home institutions.  Staff will work closely with all stakeholders in validating the project and engaging in curriculum changes, not only within the selected BTEC Business courses, but the institutions as a whole. Supported by the new online resources, staff will be instrumental in assisting future mobilities and enhancing and embedding entrepreneurship in education, in line with UK and EU proposals.

The success of the FPE mobility is due to the clear methodology developed by the consortium, through understanding the needs and impacts of all stakeholders and a project life-cycle appraisal from preparation to completion, including recruitment, learner agreements, delivery, assessment, evaluation and dissemination.  This has resulted in the development of a mobility, which has innovation of educational approaches facilitating the development of those skills relevant to respond to the increasingly complex, demanding and constantly changing job market. 

Results from previous Erasmus+ mobilities the Consortium has carried out, have far exceeded expectations in the level of impact on the learners’ professional and personal development, and on the educational delivery of our home institutions. It has allowed our partners to further develop and commit to their European Development Plan and to embed their provision in wider European understandings and networks. The unique focus and approach of this mobility will enable all partners to strengthen their experience and expertise in an area that is of high interest for educational providers and businesses within and beyond their immediate context.
ESTANCIAS INTERNACIONALES PARA ALUMNADO DEL PROGRAMA SEFED

Fundación Inform (www.inform.es) is an organization dedicated to the management, coordination and implementation of different educational programs and projects applied to VET training in Spain. It has as members of its Board the municipalities of 17 municipalities in Catalonia: Sant Pere de Ribes, Vilafranca del Penedès, Molins de Rei, El Prat de Llobregat, Santa Coloma de Gramenet, Manlleu, the Mancomunitat de Municipis de la Vall del Tenes, Lleida , Tortosa, Reus, Rubí, El Vendrell, Barcelona, Tarragona, Sabadell, Valls and Girona and the Escola Pia de Catalunya and establishes collaboration agreements with each of the VET training centers where the SEFED Program is applied (Simulation of Companies with Educational Aims) throughout Catalonia and Spain.
Our vision is to find and apply pedagogical tools to adapt the training of people to the needs of the labor market, to contribute to a qualitative improvement of the society in which we develop.
Our mission is to create, consolidate and transfer training products that facilitate the labor insertion and the continuous improvement of different groups, preferably using the methodology of business simulation.
Our values are the capacity for innovation, transnationality, transparency, quality and networking.
Since 1987 Fundación Inform manages and applies the SEFED Program in VET training for administration staff for SMEs in VET medium-level, in VET higher-level and in professional VET certificates related to the Administrative and Commercial VET family.
The transnationality of the SEFED Program has always been a key point in Inform's strategic plans and for this reason we have participated in European programs since 1987 (including 13 Leonardo Mobility projects) to try to internationalize the training received by our students and adapt it to the labour market. Since 1994, Inform is a founding member of the international network Europen-Pen International (http://www.penworldwide.org/), which brings together all the educational organizations in the world that manage simulation projects like ours. The Europen Network has 40 countries and 8,000 simulated companies in VET schools, universities, secondary schools, etc .; and we work together in various projects to advance towards common models of learning, the improvement of the professional skills of students and teachers and the development of the European labor market.

We have two types of students participating in this project.
- On the one hand, the SEFED students level 2 professional certificate ADGD0308 Administrative management activities. They are unemployed people, mostly women over 25/30 years old, with low education and mostly a lot of work experience that with the crisis have been left out of the labor market. We want to comment that the condition of being women is not a requirement of the VET project that we offer, but a reality of the current labor market.
- On the other hand students or recent graduates in VET education  and being trained by the SEFED methodology in their VET schools. They are young people from 16 to 18 years old.

The national consortium of this project consists of 56 entities that are VET schools and organizations in which the SEFED methodology is taught in part of the curriculum of VET middle level, from the VET Administrative and Commercial family, 13 of these 56 are organizations that belong to the board of Fundación Inform and in which the VET project  ADGD0308 is delivered. All these VET centers need to improve the linguistic, social and professional / technical skills of their students. We need skills and competencies of high quality and excellence so that our students can compete in the labor market. Participation and common work in European projects in a consortium coordinated by the Foundation is part of our vision and mission as an organization. We believe that transnationality must be a way of being, of working and of understanding things. And with this premise we have been working since 1987 when we started our journey in training. Transnationality is an essential point in the Foundation's strategic plan since its inception. This mission and vision is also constantly transferred to all our students and professionals who participate in the training we offer.
Vocational Training in Innovation, Entrepreneurship and Hospitality

Corkscrew 28 Day Program 



VET Learners



The Corkscrew UK programme aims to develop 75 learners from our selected VET institutes in Croatia in innovation, initiative, entrepreneurship and core employability skills. The program aims to address key strategies outlined by the European Commission in the movement of Youth across the EU. The program will develop entrepreneurial mindset through innovational training elements and vocational learning experiences. Learners will experience real time business projects working alongside startups and established entrepreneurs to develop employability skills from communication to project management. They will also receive vocational training on how to create and launch a business as they develop technical skills from website creation to online social media marketing. Learners will develop general business knowledge, confidence, initiative and an entrepreneurial mind set. 



The overall objectives are to equip learners with a new set of skills not previously gained through academic experiences or previous vocational opportunities. Our objectives also maintain on developing more opportunities for learners through increased employability and potential self-employment through the creation of further startup businesses. The skills learnt will have a long term impact on their view on business and their own professional and personal identity and also the opportunity of new business creation on the learners return to Croatia. 



VET Staff



We aim to send 6 VET staff to join a period of 7 days on the Corkscrew UK programme. The selected staff will join the initial 1st week which is predominantly focused on developing creativity through entrepreneurial challenges and innovation. The staff will shadow Corkscrew mentors and staff and learn new innovative approaches to teaching business startup and employability skill improvement in a vocational environment. The staff will develop their own understanding and confidence in replicating similar entrepreneurial environments on their return to Croatia and their own establishments. Corkscrew will share materials and knowledge to enable the most impact during the 7 day period. 



The long term benefits may be seen in more innovative approaches to teaching and training methods within domestic VET institutes and new techniques implemented within vocational settings.



IEP 10 Week Internships



The IEP  in Ireland will provide meaningful internship programmes in Ireland for 10 VET learners in duration of 10 weeks (70 days). Learners will work closely with Internship mentors to make sure their training period is providing the best opportunity in developing the core skills addressed before departure.  The 10 week Internships will focus more specifically in providing a clear work experience in their area of study, it will further develop academic experiences and allow practical growth and increased core employability skills such as project management, communication, teamwork and relevant technical skills.



For both programmes the learners will also have the opportunity in developing their linguistic skills within business environments that will improve overall employability not just in Croatia, but in the EU and globally. We feel that combined with the advancement of initiative, innovation, language and employability strengths both our targeted programmes will have a long term impact on selected learners.

The 28 day EXETER18 Programme in collaboration with Corkscrew UK, is an initiative to address and action some of the key strategies outlined by the European Union Commission. These strategies include improving and enhancing employability skills, whilst developing entrepreneurial mind sets through innovational training elements and vocational learning experiences. Learners will experience real time business projects working alongside startups and established entrepreneurs to develop employability skills from communication to project management and research to implementation, as well as receiving vocational training on how to create and launch a business from scratch developing technical skills from website creation to online social media marketing. Learners will develop IT experience, general business knowledge, confidence, initiative and an entrepreneurial mind set.

The programme has been in development over the past 5 years and it's impact has been noted across boarders and sectors in the key development of learners through vocational training and the real time project work. Access to funding will allow further learners from Sweden to enhance key employability skills and potential new business creation through innovation. High level communications and experience in logistics in operating large scale vocational programmes from both Corkscrew and Blueberry will enhance the future successes of the EXETER18 Programme.

The overall objectives are to  intensify and enhance the work skills and employability that the students today receive at our partner HVET schools. We want to bring in the international aspect of practical experience in a different country within the EU as we think  that this will be the working place for many of our partner´s students. The 28 day EXETER18 Programme aims to develop a new generation of employable Swedes with entrepreneurial drive and initiative, blended with key technical skills from IT to marketing and general business understanding. They will also be aware of multicultural professional and personal attributes from working in a multicultural business environment. Our objectives also maintain on developing more opportunities for learners through increased employability and potential self-employment through the creation of further startup businesses.

Being part of a modernization process both IHM and FSH already receive a wider range of applicants and students characterized by ethnical, cultural and functional diversity.  This also requires deeper insights and improved skills in promoting integration and inclusion from staff and learning facilitators. EXETER18 will encourage more students to improve their curriculum, international networks and international employability.

Participants profile  - As we mainly work with Higher Vocational Education and Training programmes participants are selected among a wide range of applicants studying at our schools. All this is carefully monitored and measured according to the HVET authorities recommendations and standards. The students are very committed and most of them have a clear view of their future in the business. About 90% of our students start their professional carrier directly after taking their exam. They are highly motivated and creative with a high level of innovation skills.

The learners will work within Corkscrews vocational training facility on both the real time business projects, set and mentored by local entrepreneurs and startups and training on entrepreneurship and startup tools and creation. The real time business projects will empower learners and increase confidence, whilst also developing key real time experience within a business capacity. The training will allow them to learn the skills needed to develop and launch a new business venture from highlighting potential opportunities to launching and building a new business..

Results will see an increase in initiative and confidence within business environments, but will also develop core employability strengths within a vocational setting. There will also be the potential of real time business ideas created and developed whilst on the 28 day EXETER18 Programme and will in turn impact on local economy and employment pool. 

There is a real opportunity to further develop the 28 day EXETER18 Programme as we are looking at a sustainable training model where such innovative projects can be replicated within our own and other training facilities in Sweden and across Europe. The key strategies of the programme really do fall into line with those set out in the guidance of Erasmus Plus and we feel the innovative approach to developing our learners can have a strong impact on future Erasmus Plus Programmes in Sweden and across Europe.

The WEE project offers an intensive 2 week program to participants in Exeter, UK or Barcelona in Spain, with on the job vocational work experience, with a value added training framework in business creation & entrepreneurship. This internship involves working with multinational participants in social enterprises in both locations. WEE also offers a 6 week work experience program in London, UK, based in host companies in the sector appropriate to the participants' academic qualifications. 

The project is targeted at recent graduates of VET Colleges, at EFQ levels 5 and 6. The number of participants for the WEE project will be 90 in total.

The project seeks to compliment academic qualifications with result focused work experience, enhancing learner’s employability. The project also equips and energises innovative individuals who look to create their own business, thereby creating employment for themselves, others and contributing to national and European prosperity. Participants will also learn about being innovative, creative problem solving, self-learning initiative and confidence in leadership.

It is expected that the impact of the program will be particularly felt in the employability of participants, and in the area of entrepreneurship development. Participants on completion of the program will have experience of work and develop confidence in such ‘soft skills’ as, working as part of a group, time management, prioritising work tasks etc. Participants will also develop initiative, confidence, problem solving skills and innovation skills. The work experience will be certified by a Europass Mobility document, Declaration of Attendance document and company reference on company headed paper; all of which will be of benefit when applying for jobs. Those participants with an interest in entrepreneurship will be helped to develop and concretise their business ideas by working with social entrepreneurs.
Sparking Emotional Intelligence & Employability Through Entrepreneurship

Whilst internships and work placements can provide a brief window into the working world, they do not go far enough in developing a learner’s professional skill set or provide an environment for learning the key attributes of entrepreneurship. This innovative 2 week mobility in Dublin and Barcelona addresses this by blending practical training with relevant work placements within local startup organisations.

The Sparking Emotional Intelligence & Employability Through Entrepreneurship mobility will take 88  learners enrolled on BTEC business and Enterprise Courses or BTEC Tourism and Business and 2 Enterprise staff from 4 Colleges in the UK to two of the most entrepreneurial cities in Europe and immerse them in the world of startups at cowork spaces MOB or the GEC.  Over the 2 weeks they will develop the 3 main pillars of their entrepreneurial mindsets; creative problem solving, initiative and confidence in leadership, as well as more specific technical skills in business startup such as social media marketing, branding, finance and project management.    The principles of Emotional Intelligence are embedded within the SEE Entrepreneurship mobility, enabling learners and staff to explore the personal skills fundamental to an entrepreneurial mindset, which will set them apart and influence their lifelong personal and professional attitudes. 

The vocational startup training programme developed by Corkscrew, IEP and MOB will introduce key aspects of entrepreneurship to learners and staff in a practical learning journey, developing the creative skills to spot business opportunities and identify the feasibility of an idea.  The process of lean startup will be introduced, and how to take an idea to market (website creation, social media marketing and testing). All training is conducted in a real working environment, in a live context, and directly related to the course curriculum, allowing the transfer of credits onto specific modules through the ECVET framework.  Coursework and vocational training will be enhanced and extended by the online resource developed by Corkscrew for 2017, which becomes an integral part of the SEE Entrepreneurship programme, giving access to resources, ideas and an international community of innovative thinkers.

The work experience element of the programme, also conducted at the cowork spaces in Barcelona and Dublin, enables learners to work on business projects for residents of the space, while staff shadow entrepreneurs in their daily working life. Projects will have a direct implication to the host organisations, providing a tangible work project that allows learners to develop confidence and experience in a working startup environment, making them more employable on their return to the UK.

The accompanying staff will assess, evaluate and ultimately implement the learnings of the mobility, with the targeted impact of introducing more entrepreneurial activity within education.  Staff will work closely with all stakeholders in validating the entire lifetime of the project and how best to influence curriculum, not only within the selected BTEC Business and Enterprise courses, but the institutions as a whole. Supported by the new online resources, staff will be instrumental in assisting future mobilities and enhancing and embedding entrepreneurship in education, in line with UK and EU proposals.

The success of the SEE Entrepreneurship Mobility is due to the clear methodology developed by the consortium, through understanding the needs and impacts of all stakeholders and a project life-cycle appraisal from preparation to completion, including recruitment, learner agreements, delivery, assessment, evaluation and dissemination.  This has resulted in new innovations for 2017;  the introduction of the impact of emotional intelligence on personal mindset and professional success, and the development of the Corkscrew online resources to provide ongoing wraparound support to both learners and staff as they continue in their startup journey. 

Results from previous mobilities have far exceeded expectations in the level of impact on the learners professional and personal development, and on the staff delivery of higher value course structure in the UK with EU dimensions.  The impact is also felt at institutional level as we gain interest in future EU mobility partnerships and opportunities.   A further year will allow us to build our European Development Plan, with the addition the new online platform which will extend the period of learning and influence beyond the mobility, supporting development of entrepreneurial skills and innovation both before and after the students visit the cowork facilities.  Continued access to the platform for students through their journey beyond college will continue to support their entrepreneurial mindset, allowing us to track the impacts of the SEE Entrepreneurship Mobility into the workplace.

Irish Education Partners Consortium (IEPC) has successfully applied for and is currently implementing our first Erasmus mobility project consisting of 90 participants traveling to Exeter, Barcelona and London. With over 70 participants due to start their mobility period the week after the current application deadline, IEPC is applying for a further 95 places in this application. Although this is only the second application by IEPC, its members have vast experience in mobility projects and combined sent over a thousand students abroad in the past 5 years through European funded mobility programmes.

The objectives of this project is to effect change in the attitudes and behaviours of participants. Due to the relatively short timeframe of the project, a focus on changing behaviours is key. Workplace experience is essential and the longer the experience the more beneficial for the participant; a fact that is created by our job market and the global economy. However a longer work placement period is not suitable for our participants. What we can achieve in a shorter space of time is a change to attitudes and behaviours that can have a ripple effect and create greater lasting change in a student's career and personal life and in turn, what they can contribute to those around them locally and in time at a national and potentially at an international level. Both activities in Exeter and Barcelona aim to develop entrepreneurial attitudes such as creativity, confidence and leadership.

Learners will work in groups on a project for their host company and be given a brief of the project. Projects can vary from company to company but a lot will be based around research, content creation and delivery of reports. The reports tackle business areas such as marketing, social media analysis, website analysis, improvement and creation of content and strategy, competitor analysis, customer analysis and other topics that relate to each business. In order to increase the entrepreneurial acumen of the learners, the host company and project partner will continuously reiterate the value these Startup companies have for the entrepreneur, employees and their impact locally and nationally. They will be encouraged to think of their own business ideas and access their own creativity.

In the second week of the programme, the students will be finishing their research and analysis for their host company and completing their project. From everything they have learned working for their host company, the student will then be tasked with presenting their own business idea on the last day of the programme. This final day will be a culmination of all they have learned in their host companies and the added training. It is the perfect way to display the objectives of the project by a student showing creativity in coming up with a new business idea, displaying leadership by leading, improving others or being part of a team idea and finally displaying confidence in presenting that idea in front of a group of people.

The impact of this project and it's planned activities abroad we hope will show a clear change in the student's attitude and behaviours both during and after the main activities. There will also be clear skills acquired during their mobility and we also predict an impact in the participating organisations and other groups, as we have seen in previous projects.

The impact on the participants we predict to see will be an improvement on their attitude and behaviours in favour of our objectives. We will see more creative participants with the ability to spot opportunities, come up with ideas and be able to reflect and examine those ideas to determine their value and viability. This is a cornerstone of entrepreneurship but is just as valuable to potential employers to have an employee who shows entrepreneurial traits within their organisation, an intrapreneur. Further down their professional careers we see this as being a valuable trait to possess and one that will help advance their careers.

For IEPC members, we can show our students in workplaces in Europe and working with some of the most dynamic Startups in each destination country which will have an impact on how our college is viewed locally nationally and internationally. The greater mobility of Irish students in Europe is of great benefit to the Irish government and the Department of Education. An improved workforce with, not only greater experience and attitudinal changes, but with the platform of newly learned and experienced practices, ideas and standards from different European companies, and being able to take that knowledge back to Ireland to be implemented in countless different avenues, is what the Erasmus programme is all about and it is what we hope these activities will help deliver.

Employability and Business Startup (EBS) is a further development of an innovative project designed to directly impact levels of unemployment and entrepreneurship within Ireland, targeting graduates of VET colleges, at levels 5 and 6. The project seeks to compliment academic achievement with result focused work experience, enhancing learner’s employability, and equipping and energising innovative individuals who look to create their own business, thereby creating employment for themselves, others and contributing to national and European prosperity. 
EBS offers internships in areas of study for 8 or 10 weeks, and for those seeking entrepreneurship development a choice of 2 or 4 weeks focused placements with on the job training in Social Enterprises.
The envisaged impact of the programme is that participants will have significantly increased their employability due to increased work experience, complimenting their academic qualifications, and having documented achievements (Europass Mobility, Certificate of Completion on company headed paper and company/mentor references) which will impact on future job interviews and success in finding employment.
For those interested in entrepreneurship there will be focused detailed work based experiences in social enterprises, developing and honing of business proposals, allowing those with business ideas to more confidently and with greater understanding, to bring their ideas to fruition. It is expected that the programme will increase the number of entrepreneurs, having an effect on unemployment and the development of the Irish and European economies.

Training in Entrepreneurial and Corkscrew Thinking

Whilst internships and work placements have the ability to provide a brief window into the working world, they do not go far enough in developing a learners professional skill set or provide the best environment in learning key attributes in the area of entrepreneurship. This innovative 2 week mobility in Dublin and Barcelona aims to address this issue by blending practical training in the field of startup with relevant work placements with local startup organisations.The Training in Entrepreneurship and Corkscrew Thinking (TECT) mobility will take 14 learners enrolled on BTEC business and Enterprise Courses and 2 Enterprise staff from each of Homewood School, York College, Huddersfield New College, Wigan & Leigh College and North West College and place them in two of the most entrepreneurial cities in Europe (Barcelona or Dublin) and immerse them in the world of startups at respective cowork spaces Makers of Barcelona (MOB) or the Guinness Enterprise Centre (GEC). Over the duration of the mobility they will develop the 3 main pillars of their entrepreneurial mindsets; creative problem solving, initiative and confidence in leadership, as well as more specific technical skills in business startup including social media marketing, branding, finance and project management.The vocational startup training is based on a programme developed by Corkscrew, IEP and MOB to introduce the key aspects of entrepreneurship to learners and staff in a practical learning journey. Learners and Staff will develop creative skills to spot business opportunities and how to identify the feasibility of an idea. The final part of the training will train individuals in the process of lean startup and how to take an idea to market (training in website creation, social media marketing and testing). All training is conducted in a real working environment (cowork spaces MOB & GEC) and put in a live context, not a classroom. The training is directly related to their course curriculum in the UK and through the ECVET framework will allow the transfer of credits onto specific modules.The work experience element of the programme will also be conducted at the cowork spaces in Barcelona and Dublin as the Learners work on business projects for residents of the space and staff shadow entrepreneurs in their daily working life. The projects will have a direct implication to the host organisations providing a tangible work project for the learners to develop confidence and experience in a working startup environment, and ultimately making them more employable on their return to the UK.Another key stakeholder to highlight is that of the accompanying staff from the four sending organisations within the consortium. It is these key staff that will assess, evaluate and ultimately implement the learnings of the mobility to have the targeted impact of introducing more entrepreneurial activity within education.  Staff will work closely with all stakeholders of the mobility from consortium members, receiving partners and learners in validating the entire lifetime of the project and how best to influence curriculum, not only within the selected BTEC Business and Enterprise courses, but the institutions as a whole. The staff will be instrumental in assisting future mobilities and enhancing entrepreneurship in education, again in line with UK and EU proposals.It is important that the TECT Mobility is successful for a second year, therefore, the consortium has spent time and effort in developing a clear methodology to carry out the project from understanding all stakeholders needs and impacts and also a project life-cycle appraisal from preparation to completion (including recruitment, learner agreements, delivery, assessment, evaluation and dissemination). It has also been important to ensure clear MoUs with all relevant parties to ensure clear guidelines during the implementation of the mobility.From our first KA1 mobility in 2015 we have seen results that have exceeded our expectations in the level of impact on the learners professional and personal development and on the staffs potential in delivering higher value course structure in the UK with EU dimensions. We also feel the impact has been felt at institutional level as we gain interest in future EU mobility partnerships and opportunities. A second round of funding will allow us to build on our European Development Plan as we include new members in the consortium (North West Regional College) and a further partner in delivering this innovative programme in Barcelona (Makers of Barcelona).

The innovative two-week Vocational Enterprise StartUp Programme Ireland (VESPI) is an exciting mobility addressing the core entrepreneurial goals of the key stakeholders of the consortium (including learners, staff & institutions) as well as wider UK and European targets as highlighted in Lord Young’s Enterprise for All in the UK and the EU Commission’s 2020 Entrepreneurship Plan. The VESPI mobility will take 60 learners (aged 15-24) enrolled on BTEC Business and Enterprise Courses (Extended Diploma and Level 3/5) and develop the 3 main pillars of their entrepreneurial mind-sets (creative problem solving, initiative and confidence in leadership) through vocational training in the startup business cycle and elements of work experience at an innovative co-work space in the top entrepreneurial city in Europe - Dublin. 

The consortium was developed through a shared commitment to develop more entrepreneurial activity in education as well as an aligned European Development Plan that would positively impact the key shareholders. The UK consortium is made up of 4 sending organisations, including Homewood School, York College, Huddersfield New College and Wigan & Leigh College (all of whom have begun movements to create more vocational and enterprising opportunities for learners and staff) and Corkscrew StartUp School, the lead applicant and VET organisation focusing on developing entrepreneurship within education. The consortium and receiving partners in Ireland (IEP & GEC) will use the EU mobility as a way to develop standards and practices that can be used for future partnerships. The mobility will increase the European dimensions of the consortium and will allow further submissions in following years to increase the opportunities for learners across multiple disciplines.

Whilst the consortium members and partners have clear objectives on an institutional basis, the main focus of the mobility is on the selected learners and how the unique experience will allow them to develop critical core competencies in their professional and personal development, ultimately leading to them becoming more entrepreneurial & employable. The vocational training is focused on key practices in the creation, launch and operations of a startup business including relevant technical skills such as business development, marketing, web creation and lean startup methodology. The training is directly related to their course curriculum in the UK and, through the ECVET framework, will allow the transfer of credits onto specific modules. In respect of the real time work experience (from the startup business located at the GEC cowork space) the learners will get first hand work experience within true startups that will boost relevant tech skills and other core competencies for increased employability options and entrepreneurial understanding. By working in Dublin (one of the top startup cities in the world and the best in Europe) they will get an unrivaled experience to further develop startup understanding and qualities through tangible new enterprise experiences.

The third key stakeholder to highlight is that of the accompanying staff from the three sending organisations within the consortium. It is these key staff that will assess, evaluate and ultimately implement the learnings of the mobility to have the targeted impact of introducing more entrepreneurial activity within education.  Staff will work closely with all stakeholders of the mobility from consortium members, receiving partners and learners in validating the entire lifetime of the project and how best to influence curriculum, not only within the selected BTEC Business and Enterprise courses, but the institutions as a whole. The staff will be instrumental in assisting future mobilities and enhancing entrepreneurship in education, again in line with UK and EU proposals.

It is important that the VESPI Mobility is an operational success, therefore the consortium has spent time and effort in developing a clear methodology to carry out the project, from understanding all stakeholders needs and impacts and also a project life-cycle appraisal from preparation to completion (including recruitment, learner agreements, delivery, assessment, evaluation and dissemination). It has also been important to ensure clear MoUs with all relevant parties to ensure clear guidelines during the implementation of the mobility.

We envisage that the results received from the VESPI mobility will have an impact on the learners’ professional and personal development and on the staff’s potential in delivering higher value course structure in the UK with EU dimensions. We also feel the impact will be felt at institutional level as we gain interest in future EU mobility partnerships and opportunities. Our partners in Ireland will also benefit from working with us in the mobility as they increase abilities in the delivery of key vocational training and work elements within the field of entrepreneurship.
